description: From 1 April 2025, New Zealand's progressive personal income tax thresholds are adjusted. The first $15,600 of taxable income is taxed at 10.5%; income between $15,601 and $53,500 at 17.5%; $53,501 to $78,100 at 30%; $78,101 to $180,000 at 33%; and any income over $180,000 at 39%.

For the 2024‑25 income year (1 April 2024 to 31 March 2025), the government introduced transitional income‑tax thresholds. Income up to $15,600 is taxed at 10.5% and the next slice ($15,601–$48,000) at the usual 17.5% rate. To preserve progressivity where thresholds changed part‑way through the year, composite marginal rates of 12.82% for income between $48,001–$53,500, 21.64% for $53,501–$70,000 and 30.99% for $70,001–$78,100 apply. Incomes from $78,101–$180,000 are taxed at 33% and income over $180,000 at 39%.

The Taxation (Income Tax Rate and Other Amendments) Act 2020 introduced a new top personal income‑tax bracket effective from 1 April 2021. The first $14,000 of income is taxed at 10.5%; $14,001–$48,000 at 17.5%; $48,001–$70,000 at 30%; $70,001–$180,000 at 33%; and income over $180,000 at 39%. The research brief published by the New Zealand Parliamentary Library highlights that this change created a new 39% bracket while retaining the lower brackets unchanged.

A two‑stage tax cut programme was enacted in 2010. Up to 30 September 2010, the existing schedule (in force since 1 April 2010) taxed the first $14,000 of income at 12.5%, the next $34,000 ($14,001–$48,000) at 21%, $48,001–$70,000 at 33% and income above $70,000 at 38%. From 1 October 2010, Budget 2010 reduced these rates to 10.5%, 17.5%, 30% and 33% respectively and aligned them with reductions in the goods and services tax. Beehive releases confirm that the top personal tax rate was cut from 38% to 33%.

The Taxation (Personal Tax Cuts, Annual Rates, and Remedial Matters) Act 2008 provided across‑the‑board tax cuts from 1 October 2008. The income tax schedule effective from 1 April 2008 to 30 September 2008 had multiple narrow brackets: 13.75% for the first $9,500 of income, 16.75% on $9,501–$14,000, 21% on $14,001–$38,000, 27% on $38,001–$40,000, 33% on $40,001–$60,000, 36% on $60,001–$70,000 and 39% on income above $70,000. These cuts simplified the structure. From 1 October 2008 the first two bands merged and rates were reduced: 12.5% on the first $14,000, 21% on $14,001–$40,000, 33% on $40,001–$70,000 and 39% above $70,000.

For the 2005–06 income year (and continuing from the 2000 reforms), New Zealand used four marginal rates. The first $38,000 of income was taxed at an effective 19.5% (achieved through a 15% statutory rate with a low‑income earner rebate); income between $38,001 and $60,000 was taxed at 33%; and income above $60,000 at 39%. The Taxation (Tax Rate Increase) legislation introduced this 39% top rate from April 2000, while a Parliamentary Library research brief notes that these thresholds remained unchanged through the mid‑2000s.

Legislation introduced in December 1999 raised the top personal income tax rate from 33% to 39% on income over $60,000 effective 1 April 2000. The lower rates remained unchanged: the first band was taxed at 15% (with a low‑income rebate giving an effective 19.5% marginal rate), the second band at 21%, and the third band at 33%.

By 1989–90, extensive tax reforms had reduced New Zealand’s top personal marginal tax rate to 33%. The Taxation Reform legislation created a broad‑based, low‑rate system with two main brackets: income up to about $30,875 was taxed at 24%, and income above that level at 33%.
In the mid‑1980s New Zealand still had a very high top personal income tax rate. Te Ara’s data on top marginal rates shows that the top personal rate stood at 67% in 1985.
According to Te Ara’s historical data, the top personal marginal tax rate was about 60% in 1980. Multiple brackets existed, but detailed thresholds are not readily available.
The top personal income tax rate had fallen to about 50% by 1975. Detailed threshold information for this period is scarce.
During the early 1970s the top personal rate remained high at roughly 68% and the tax scale included many progressive steps. Specific thresholds are not easily accessible from available sources.
Historical data indicate that New Zealand’s top personal rate was about 68% in the mid‑1960s.
In 1960 the top personal marginal rate remained around 68% with a highly graduated tax scale.
Te Ara’s data show that the top personal marginal income tax rate was about 68% in 1955.
By 1950 the top personal marginal rate had fallen from the wartime high but still stood at around 77%.
During World War II personal tax rates were very high. Te Ara’s data show the top marginal rate reached about 90% in 1945.
At the start of the Second World War the top personal rate climbed to around 87%.
By the mid‑1930s, New Zealand’s top personal tax rate was approximately 44%.
Around 1930 the top personal marginal tax rate was roughly 25%.
In the mid‑1920s the top personal tax rate was about 22%.
Following World War I the top personal marginal tax rate rose to roughly 38%.
During the First World War the top personal tax rate increased to about 12%.
By 1910 the top personal income tax rate was about 6%.
At the start of the 20th century the top personal tax rate remained around 5%.
By 1900 the top personal tax rate was about 5%.
A few years after the introduction of income tax the top personal rate was approximately 5%.
The Liberal Government introduced New Zealand’s first income tax in 1891. Incomes under £300 were exempt, and the top rate was 5% on incomes above £1,000.
Prior to the introduction of income tax, there was no personal income tax; the top personal tax rate was effectively zero.

Working for Families tax credits: Family tax credit weekly payments increased from 1 April 2024. The eldest child credit increased from $136 to $144 per week after tax (annual $7,524). Each subsequent child credit increased from $111 to $117 per week after tax (annual $6,130).

The In-Work Tax Credit (IWTC) for families with up to three children increased by $25 per week. The base rate changed from $3,770 per year (about $72.50 per week) to $5,070 per year (about $97.50 per week).

Minimum family tax credit guarantees families who work a minimum number of hours (20 hours for sole parents or 30 combined hours for couples) a minimum after‑tax income of $679 per week ($35,316 per year) if their net family income is below that level. The guarantee and threshold can change annually.

Best Start tax credit provides $73 per week up to a maximum of $3,838 in the first year of a baby’s life. Budget 2025 applies an income test to the first year (previously flat). The credit already has abatement applied in the second and third years.

FamilyBoost tax credit was introduced on 1 July 2024. It refunds 25% of licensed early childhood education fees up to NZ$975 per quarter for households earning up to $35,000 per quarter. The credit abates at 9.75 cents for every dollar of quarterly household income above $35,000 and is zero when income reaches $45,000.

KiwiSaver: Employers must contribute at least 3% of employees’ before-tax pay (subject to employer superannuation contribution tax). The government contributes $260.72 annually when members contribute at least $1,042.86 between 1 July and 30 June, otherwise 25 cents for every dollar contributed. From 1 April 2026 the default employer and employee contribution rate will increase to 3.5%, and from 1 April 2028 it will rise to 4%.

Student loan borrowers must repay 12% of all income above the annual repayment threshold. For 2026 the threshold is $24,128, corresponding to weekly threshold of $464. Repayments from secondary jobs have no threshold – 12% is deducted from all earnings.

Paid parental leave provides a maximum weekly payment that increases each year. Rates (before tax) are: $661.12 per week from 1 July 2022 to 30 June 2023, $712.17 per week for 2023–24, $754.87 per week for 2024–25, and $788.66 per week for 2025–26.

ACC earners' levy rate under the Accident Compensation (Earners' Levy) Regulations 2010: current portion $1.7245 per $100 of earnings and residual portion $0.0533 per $100 (combined rate 1.7778%). Maximum earnings are capped at $110,018 for employees and $106,473 for self‑employed. The levy applies to all liable earnings up to the cap.

ACC earners' levy rate under the Accident Compensation (Earners' Levy) Regulations 2009: current portion $1.4320 per $100 and residual portion $0.0790 per $100 (combined rate 1.511%). Maximum earnings capped at $106,473 for employees and $102,922 for self‑employed.

ACC earners' levy rate under the Accident Compensation (Earners' Levy) Regulations 2008: earners pay $1.2444 per $100 of earnings (1.2444%). Maximum earnings are $102,922 for employees and $99,817 for self‑employed. A low‑earnings exemption applied for self‑employed people with net income below $21,320 or $17,056 (depending on age).

ACC earners' levy rate under the Accident Compensation (Earners' Levy) Regulations 2007: earners pay $1.1556 per $100 of earnings (1.1556%). Maximum earnings are $99,817 for employees and $96,619 for self‑employed. Low‑earnings thresholds were $19,760 for earners over 18 and $15,808 for those under 18.

KiwiSaver compulsory employer contributions phased in from 1 April 2008. From 1 April 2008 employers had to contribute at least 1% of each employee's gross salary or wages when KiwiSaver deductions were made.
The compulsory employer contribution rate for KiwiSaver increased to 2% of gross salary or wages from 1 April 2009.
The compulsory employer contribution rate for KiwiSaver increased to 3% of gross salary or wages from 1 April 2010.
The compulsory employer contribution rate for KiwiSaver increased to 4% of gross salary or wages from 1 April 2011, completing the phased introduction of employer contributions.

Stage 1 of the Working for Families package took effect from 1 April 2005. Family tax credit rates were increased by $25 for the first child and $15 for each additional child. The child component of main income‑tested benefits was folded into the family tax credit, and foster care, unsupported child’s and orphan’s benefits increased by $15 per week. Accommodation supplement rates were also increased in high‑cost areas.

Stage 2 of the Working for Families package began on 1 April 2006. The In‑work Tax Credit replaced the Child Tax Credit, paying up to $60 per week to families with three children and $15 per week for each additional child. The minimum family tax credit threshold rose from $15,080 to $17,680. Abatement thresholds were consolidated into a single $35,000 threshold, and the abatement rate on family tax credits was reduced to 20%.

Stage 3 of the Working for Families package took effect from 1 April 2007. Family tax credit rates increased by $10 per child. The minimum family tax credit threshold was lifted to $18,044, and the Income Tax Act 2007 introduced indexation of family tax credit amounts and abatement thresholds to cumulative inflation.

rates.component: Family tax credit increase per child

description: From 1 April 2008 the after‑tax income threshold for the minimum family tax credit increased to $18,460. The Income Tax Act 2007 also provided for inflation‑based adjustments when the consumer price index moved by at least 5%.
From 1 April 2009 the after‑tax income threshold for the minimum family tax credit increased to $20,540.
From 1 April 2010 the after‑tax income threshold for the minimum family tax credit increased to $20,800.
From 1 April 2011 the after‑tax income threshold for the minimum family tax credit increased to $22,204.
The Income Tax (Minimum Family Tax Credit) Order 2011 increased the amount used in the minimum family tax credit formula to $22,568 for the 2012–13 tax year.
The Income Tax (Minimum Family Tax Credit) Order 2012 increased the minimum family tax credit threshold to $22,724 for the 2013–14 tax year and later years.

From 1 April 2022 the family tax credit increased by $15 per week for the eldest child and $13 per week for each subsequent child. The Best Start tax credit increased to $65 per week. The minimum family tax credit threshold increased from $31,096 to $32,864 and the abatement rate rose from 25% to 27%.

In recent years the minimum family tax credit guarantees working families a minimum annual income after tax. As at the 2025/26 year the credit ensures a net family income of $35,316 per year ($679 per week) when families meet work‑hour requirements.
